segment.tokens: There was a show-bill

printed during the reign of Queen Anne , a copy of which is still to be seen in one of the public libraries in England , to the following effect : " To be seen , at the Ship , upon Great Tower Hill , the finest taught horse in the world

of Queen Anne , a copy of which is still to be seen in one of the public libraries in England , to the following effect : " To be seen , at the Ship , upon Great Tower Hill , the finest taught horse in the world
He fetches like a spaniel dog
He carries
If you hide a glove a handkerchief a door key a pewter spoon so small a thing as a silver twopence
he will seek about the room
till he has found it
then he will bring it to his master
He will also tell the number of spots on a card "
He leap through a hoop with a variety of other curious performances
The story of Alexander the Great , and his favorite horse Bucephalus , doubtless
most of my readers have heard before
Bucephalus was a of a very high spirit , which had been sent to Philip , Alexander 's father , when the latter was a boy
a very high spirit had been sent to Philip , Alexander 's father , when the latter was a boy
when the latter was a
This horse was taken out into one of the parks connected with the palace
connected with the palace
the king many of his courtiers went to see him
The horse pranced about so furiously
that every body was of him
He seemed perfectly unmanageable
No one was to risk his life mounting such an unruly animal
Philip was inclined to be in ill humor about it
In the mean time the boy Alexander stood quietly by watching all the motions of the horse seeming to be studying his character
Philip had decided
that the horse was
the horse had given orders to have
him sent back to Thessaly , where he came from
to Thessaly , where he came from
Alexander did not much like the idea of losing so fine an animal
Alexander begged his father to allow him to mount the horse
Philip at first refused
thinking
the risk was too
But he finally consented
after his son had urged him a great while
So Alexander went up to the horse
Alexander took hold of his bridle
He patted him upon the neck
He soothed him with his voice
showing him at the same time his easy unconcerned manner
that he was not in the least afraid of him
Bucephalus was calmed the presence of Alexander
Bucephalus subdued
He allowed himself to be caressed
Alexander turned his head in such a direction as to prevent his
seeing his own shadow
his own shadow had before appeared to frighten him
Then he threw off his cloak
he sprang upon the back of the horse
he let
him go as fast as he pleased
The animal flew across the plain at the top of his speed
while the king his courtiers looked on first with extreme fear afterward with the greatest admiration pleasure
had
got
When Bucephalus tired running he was easily reined in
Alexander returned to the king , who praised him very highly
the king praised him very highly
Alexander told him
that he deserved a larger kingdom than Macedon
Alexander had a larger kingdom some years after a great deal larger one
though that is a of another story
Bucephalus became the favorite horse of Alexander docile
Bucephalus was very docile though full of life and spirit
He would kneel upon his fore legs at the command of his master
in order that he might mount more easily
A great many anecdotes are related of the feats of Bucephalus , as a war-horse
He was never to have
any one ride him Alexander
When the horse died
Alexander mourned for him a great deal
He had
him buried with great solemnity
He built a small city upon the spot of his interment , which he named , in honor of his favorite , Bucephalia
his interment he named
called her master Nancy
An odd sort of an old mare , called by her master Nancy , used to go by my father 's house , when I was a child
when I was a
She was the of Peter Packer -- Uncle Peter he withal quite as odd as his mare
as he was sometimes called the good people in our neighborhood
he was the of the weekly newspaper withal quite as odd as his mare
he was
As long as I can remember
Uncle Peter went his weekly rounds
for aught I know
he is going to this day
No storm tempest snow-bank could detain him
him is not longer than a day or two in his mission
He was a very punctual
in other words he always paced leisurely along some time another
Speaking of pacing reminds me
that the mare aforesaid belonged to that particular class and order called _ pacers _ from their peculiar gait
called _ pacers _
I should think too
that the mare was not unlike the celebrated animal on which Don Quixote rode in pursuit of wind-mills , and things of that sort
unlike the celebrated animal on which Don Quixote rode in pursuit of wind-mills , and things of that sort
But she had one peculiarity the faculty of diagonal or oblique locomotion
one peculiarity is not set down in the description of Rozinante to wit the faculty of diagonal or oblique locomotion
This mare of Uncle Peter 's went forward something after the fashion of a crab a little like a ship with the wind abeam
as the sailors would say
It was a standing of dispute among us school-boys , whether the animal went head foremost or not
whether the animal went head foremost not
that did not matter much practically
But it is
so that she always made her circuit
that she did
as I have said before
Sometimes she was a day or two later than usual
that seldom occurred except in the summer season
when it did happen
it was on this wise
she had a most passionate love for the study of practical botany
not being allowed when at home to pursue her favorite science as often owing partly to a
as she wished
want of specimens partly to her master desire to educate her in the more solid branches
he was a great for the solid branches
she frequently took the liberty to divest herself of her bridle when standing at the door of her master 's customers to pace away in search of the dear flowers
Oh she was a devoted of botany
that her desire to obtain botanical specimens did sometimes interfere a good deal with her other literary and scientific engagements
She used to do very nearly
as she chose
Uncle Peter seldom crossed her in her inclinations
If she was along the highway
she felt a little thirsty
she never hesitated to stop
whether her master invited her to do so not at a brook or a watering-trough
Uncle Peter used to say
that he never tried to prevent these liberties but once
he had occasion to repent bitterly of that
A thunder-storm was coming on
he was in a hurry to get to the next house
But the mare was determined
before she went any further to stop at a stream of water and drink
He set out to have his way
Nancy set out to have hers
The result was
that Peter was obliged to yield
But that was not the of it
The old mare was so much vexed
because her master disputed her will
while she was standing in the brook
that she threw up her hind feet
she let
him fall over her head into the water
That gentle correction cured Uncle Peter
She had her own way after the ducking
